messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-05-28T12:10:49Z
## Message ID: 20170528-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Intensifying space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 7 (strong) during the synoptic period 2017-05-28T06:00Z to 2017-05-28T09:00Z. 

The storm is caused by the arrival of the CME with ID 2017-05-23T05:00:00-CME-001.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-05-27T21:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes: 

This event is associated with Interplanetary Shock with ID 2017-05-27T14:47:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20170527-AL-001).



NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Interplanetary Shock
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-05-27T21:28:04Z
## Message ID: 20170527-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by ACE at L1 at 2017-05-27T14:47Z. 

The shock is caused by CME with ID 2017-05-23T05:00:00-CME-001 (see notification 20170523-AL-002).  Strong magnetospheric compression and geomagnetic storm are possible.

Activity ID: 2017-05-27T14:47:00-IPS-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-05-25T12:10:45Z
## Message ID: 20170525-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux continues to be above the threshold of 10^5 pfu as of 2017-05-25T09:45Z, with the original radiation belt enhancement starting at 2017-05-21T12:25Z (see notifications 20170521-AL-002 and 20170523-AL-001).

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-05-19T18:08Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-05-21T12:25:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 17, 2017 - May 23, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-05-25T01:36:56Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-05-17T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-05-23T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170525-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the S-type CME (<500 km/s) that started on 2017-05-23T05:00Z may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth around 2017-05-26T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20170523-AL-002).  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during several synoptic periods from 2017-05-20T00:00Z to 2017-05-20T18:00Z.  This slight enhancement in the geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-05-19.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2017-05-18.  Solar wind speed values reached >600 km/s on 2017-05-19.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-05-21T12:25Z.  The significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 have remained elevated since 2015-05-21 crossing the threshold several times.  This elevation in the electron flux is associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20170521-AL-001, 20170521-AL-002, and 20170523-AL-001).   

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-05-21T01:36Z     ~565            C               -90/-12               13                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-05-24T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-05-30T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions on the solar disk that could produce solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  Currently, the > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt is enhanced to values of ~98,000 pfu due to the high speed stream described above.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-05-23T22:59:29Z
## Message ID: 20170523-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-05-23T05:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~375 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 26 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 12/-7 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2017-05-23T05:00:00-CME-001

 
Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME will have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2017-05-26T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2017-05-23T05:00:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170523_152700_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170523_152700_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170523_152700_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170523_152700_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170523_152700_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170523_152700_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170523_152700_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-05-23T19:56:56Z
## Message ID: 20170523-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt.  GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-05-21T12:25Z (see recent notification 20170521-AL-002). Electron flux is currently below this threshold, but has remained elevated throughout the past two days.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by high speed stream starting at 2017-05-19T18:08Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-05-21T12:25:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Auto-generated Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-05-21T12:36:50Z
## Message ID: 20170521-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-05-21T12:25Z. 


NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-05-21T12:25:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 10, 2017 - May 16, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-05-18T03:52:05Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-05-10T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-05-16T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170518-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the S-type CME starting on 2017-05-13T22:00Z (~340 km/s) will have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth around 2017-05-17T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20170515-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2017-05-15T09:00Z-12:00Z and 2017-05-15T18:00Z-21:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was caused by the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-05-15. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-05-17T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-05-23T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions on the far side of the sun and several that will rotate to the Earth's facing solar disk in the next few days that could produce solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week.  Currently, solar wind conditions at Earth are going back to nominal levels after being under the influence of the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  Another coronal hole high speed stream is expected to arrive at L1 around 2017-05-20.  On its last rotation, this high speed stream increased geomagnetic activity to moderate levels and elevated the energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-05-15T14:47:17Z
## Message ID: 20170515-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-05-13T22:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~340 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 25 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 4/-23 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2017-05-13T22:00:00-CME-001

 
Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2017-05-17T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected maximum Kp index is below minor.

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2017-05-13T22:00:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170514_070200_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170514_070200_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170514_070200_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170514_070200_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170514_070200_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170514_070200_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20170514_070200_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 03, 2017 - May 09, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-05-10T21:51:48Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-05-03T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-05-09T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170510-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.   No CMEs traveling above 500 km/s where detected in the available coronagraph imagery.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2017-05-04T21:00Z-24:00Z.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2017-05-04.  Solar wind speed values reached >500 km/s on 2017-05-05.  A second coronal hole high speed stream was detected on 2017-05-09.  The solar wind speed values reached values of >600 km/s on 2017-05-10.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-05-10T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-05-16T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are some active regions on the far side of the Sun as seen on the STEREO A EUVI images that could be capable of producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream by the end of the next reporting period.

ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 26, 2017 - May 02, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-05-03T23:35:47Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-04-26T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-05-02T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170503-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for several periods between 2017-04-26T10:20Z - 2017-04-27T00:55Z, 2017-04-27T06:37Z - 2017-04-28T00:05Z and 2017-04-28T08:45Z - 2017-04-28T21:45Z.  This enhancement on the energetic electron flux was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream that started on 2017-04-21 (see notifications 20170423-AL-002, 20170425-AL-001, and 20170427-AL-001).  


The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the enhanced electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.  


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-04-28T21:24Z     ~580            C               -97/2                 17                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-05-03T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-05-09T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week as there are only a few very small active regions present on the solar surface. STEREO A is expected to enter a coronal hole high speed stream this coming week due to the large equatorial CH currently close to disk center.
